title: Palindrome Number
description: Given an integer x, return true if x is a palindrome, and false otherwise.

examples.explanation: 121 reads as 121 from left to right and from right to left.
From left to right, it reads -121. From right to left, it becomes 121-. Therefore it is not a palindrome.

brute-force.name: String Conversion
brute-force.description: Convert the number to a string and check if it reads the same forwards and backwards.

steps.instruction: Define the function is_palindrome that takes an integer x.
Convert the integer to a string.
Return true if the string is equal to its reverse.
steps.hint: Use slicing `[::-1]` to reverse the string.

optimal.name: Revert Half
optimal.description: Revert the second half of the number and compare it with the first half.

steps.instruction: Define the function is_palindrome that takes an integer x.
Handle edge cases: negative numbers or numbers ending in 0 (except 0 itself) are not palindromes.
steps.placeholderCode: if x < 0 or (x % 10 == 0 and x != 0): return False
steps.hint: Negative numbers and numbers ending in 0 (except 0) cannot be palindromes.
steps.solutionCode: if x < 0 or (x % 10 == 0 and x != 0): return False

steps.instruction: Initialize a variable to store the reversed half of the number.
Loop until the original number is greater than the reversed number.
Add the last digit of x to the reversed number.
steps.hint: We build the reverse number digit by digit.\nExample: If x is 123, we take 3 (123 % 10), then 2, then 1.\nreverted_number becomes 3, then 32, then 321.

steps.instruction: Remove the last digit from x.
Check if the original number equals the reversed number (or reversed/10 for odd lengths).
steps.placeholderCode: return x == reverted_number or x == reverted_number // 10
steps.hint: Compare `x` with `reverted_number`. For odd lengths, divide `reverted_number` by 10.
